unnormalised: Okay, so you're thinking about Fintech in India, huh? It's a total game-changer, right? Gone are the days of waiting in those endless bank queues. Now everything's on your phone. But it's also kinda confusing, isn't it? Let's break it down, bhai.
normalised: Okay, so you're thinking about Fintech in India, huh? It's a total game-changer, right? Gone are the days of waiting in those endless bank queues. Now everything's on your phone. But it's also kinda confusing, isn't it? Let's break it down, bhai.

unnormalised: First off, UPI is king. Everyone uses it! From buying chai at a tapri for Rs. 10 to paying rent of Rs 25,000, UPI is just... everywhere. It's powered by so many apps, GPay, PhonePe, Paytm, you name it. The no. of transactions is mind-blowing, crossing billions every month!
normalised: First off, U-P-I is king. Everyone uses it! From buying chai at a tapri for rupee ten to paying rent of rupee twenty five thousand, U-P-I is just... everywhere. It's powered by so many apps, G-Pay, PhonePe, Paytm, you name it. The number of transactions is mind-blowing, crossing billions every month!

unnormalised: Then there are the digital wallets. Remember when Paytm was all the rage after demonetisation back in 2016? While UPI kinda took over, wallets are still useful, especially for cashback offers. Plus, some older folks are more comfortable with a wallet balance than directly linking their bank accounts. And the best thing is that you can do almost everything from them like paying ur electricity bill which amounts to Rs 2345 to paying ur water bill in your Municipal corporation.
normalised: Then there are the digital wallets. Remember when Paytm was all the rage after demonetisation back in two thousand and sixteen? While U-P-I kinda took over, wallets are still useful, especially for cashback offers. Plus, some older folks are more comfortable with a wallet balance than directly linking their bank accounts. And the best thing is that you can do almost everything from them like paying your electricity bill which amounts to rupee two thousand three hundred and forty five to paying your water bill in your Municipal corporation.

unnormalised: But Fintech isn't just about payments. It's also about lending. You can now get instant personal loans via apps, sometimes disbursed in under 5 mins! Pretty crazy, right? Of course, you gotta be careful about interest rates (typically around 12-24% p.a.) and hidden charges. Read the fine print, ya!
normalised: But Fintech isn't just about payments. It's also about lending. You can now get instant personal loans via apps, sometimes disbursed in under five minutes! Pretty crazy, right? Of course, you gotta be careful about interest rates (typically around twelve to twenty four percent per annum) and hidden charges. Read the fine print, ya!

unnormalised: And then there's investing. Suddenly, everyone's a stock market expert, thanks to apps like Zerodha, Groww, and Upstox. You can start with as little as Rs. 500, invest in mutual funds, or even dabble in IPOs. Just remember, it's not a get-rich-quick scheme. *Do your research*.
normalised: And then there's investing. Suddenly, everyone's a stock market expert, thanks to apps like Zerodha, Groww, and Upstox. You can start with as little as rupee five hundred, invest in mutual funds, or even dabble in I-P-O-s. Just remember, it's not a get-rich-quick scheme. Do your research.

unnormalised: A big deal these days is also buy now pay later (BNPL). A lot of people are buying expensive stuff like phones and other electronics using BNPL. A typical phone costing around ₹30000 is paid in 6 months EMI.
normalised: A big deal these days is also buy now pay later (B-N-P-L). A lot of people are buying expensive stuff like phones and other electronics using B-N-P-L. A typical phone costing around rupee thirty thousand is paid in six months E-M-I.

unnormalised: However, it is not all sunshine and rainbows. One thing that I am concerned about is the cybersecurity. I am always concerned about my account security and hope it is foolproof so that even after cyberattacks like that of a few weeks back, nothing affects my account.

unnormalised: So, yeah, Fintech in India is a wild ride. It's made life easier and more accessible, but it also comes with its own set of challenges.
